That in the universe of asbestos victims, if one were to have a line, one would certainly put at the head of the line the people who get this virulent form of cancer, and maybe next you'd go down to the asbestosis victims, and then I suppose the last people you would get to are the people who have... have had exposure, but haven't manifested anything.
So in... by pressing these claims, aren't you putting at risk people who, 20, 30, 40 years from now, will develop a dread disease?

turn.speaker: charles_c_goetsch
turn.label: Mr. Charles C. Goetsch
turn.text: Not as far as the defendants in this case, which are railroads, are concerned.
It's a very narrow class of plaintiffs that we're addressing here.
We're not addressing general common law plaintiffs or defendants.
We're simply talking about the... the FELA.

And what the Snowmen are asking this Court to do is to interpret and apply the FELA in such a way that railroads will not even think about doing this... exposing their workers to a known carcinogen, without any warning, training or protection, in order to save money... thereby... it's--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well, what I would imagine, in terms of the deterrence, a large number of people will get cancer, will get these diseases and will have undoubted enormous liability.

turn.speaker: charles_c_goetsch
turn.label: Mr. Charles C. Goetsch
turn.text: --Well, in--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: So what... I mean--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --And what I'm worried about very much is what Justice Ginsburg pointed out.

I mean, to what extent, by allowing a universal cause of action for the medical, will we... for the medical testing... will we in fact interfere with the people who are undoubtedly hurt... that is, who have the disease... from getting recovery.
Is the answer to that zero?

turn.speaker: charles_c_goetsch
turn.label: Mr. Charles C. Goetsch
turn.text: --I'm sorry, Your Honor, what--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Is the case that there is or there isn't a serious practical concern that if people can recover... often extra, because they have the tests anyway... for all this testing, that there will be significant interference with recovery by people who do have the disease?

turn.speaker: charles_c_goetsch
turn.label: Mr. Charles C. Goetsch
turn.text: --Not... I do not believe so in the case of the railroads, especially--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well, if you couldn't stop the principle from spreading.

turn.speaker: charles_c_goetsch
turn.label: Mr. Charles C. Goetsch
turn.text: --Well, I think that this Court can and should make it clear that this is an FELA case based on the policies and concerns of the FELA, which the common law does not share.
Medical monitoring will enable these individuals to detect the disease early and hopefully beneficially treat it.
So they don't have to die and bring a wrongful death case later on.

I mean the whole point of this is to mitigate and to reduce society's burden and the railroads' long-term burden for paying damages as a result of its negligent conduct in violation of the FELA, in violation of OSHA, in violation of these... these human beings' who happen to be railroad workers' legally protected duty to be free from this type of exposure to a known carcinogen.
And if the railroads are not held economically accountable under the FELA for this type of conduct, they will have no meaningful economic incentive to avoid it in the future.
Indeed, they can save substantial amounts of money by doing this again.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well, that doesn't really follow.
Because isn't the hypothesis that maybe 1 out of 100 or 1 out of 50... that some of these people are going to get cancer, and when they do, they'll have a tremendous recovery?

turn.speaker: charles_c_goetsch
turn.label: Mr. Charles C. Goetsch
turn.text: In 20 to 30 to 40 years, Your Honor, when witnesses are dead and gone, documents lost and destroyed, the railroad merged and bankrupt, and the railroad says okay, you're dying of cancer, now prove it.
That's not enough of a deterrent to stop what's happening now.
They don't want to be subject to this--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: I think you've answered the question, Mr. Goetsch.
The case is submitted.
